noun.description: A small waterfall, typically one of several that fall in stages down a steep rocky slope.
A process whereby something, typically information or knowledge, is successively passed on.
examples: the greater the number of people who are well briefed, the wider the cascade effect

verb.description: (of water) pour downward rapidly and in large quantities.
examples: water was cascading down the stairs

verb.description: Arrange (a number of devices or objects) in a series or sequence.

origin: Mid 17th century: from French, from Italian cascata, from cascare to fall, based on Latin casus (see case).
